attributes.title: A Step Towards the Culture of Scientific Communication
attributes.description: Description of the functional interactive model for indicating the status of the scientific community in real time

summary.value:
Further, in Russian, and then in English, the idea of an innovative project for an interactive network indicator of the state of the scientific community is described.
The need for such an indicator as an experimental tool is due to research objectives. Today, without fixing unambiguous quantitative indicators, it is difficult to imagine the possibility of trust in the results of social research. But this is only one of the complexes of problems that one encounters when observing the state of the scientific community.
One of the pressing problems remains the fixation of the social influence of science. Existing indices of scientific influence are not perfect, possibly because only individual indicators are measured and taken into account. The proposed model of the indicator of academic freedom and openness (AFOI = GBI) is comprehensive. It is aimed at measuring in real time the movement of science from closed to open forms, taking into account the value of scientific work and the participation of not only high-level professionals and experts, but also their students in the very first stages of training.
The state of science cannot be studied outside of social factors, just as the impact of science on society is not limited to citation indicators. Therefore, the idea of a comprehensive indicator arose.
Based on a survey of the scientific community, which includes not only academics, but also students, it is possible to comprehensively record the impact of science on society, and society on science.
What does it give?
The hypothesis is that the desired state of the scientific community (green) and its movement should be measured by a dynamic, spectral indicator (GBI). The vector of development of science is important, which is inseparable from the vector of development of society, and not individual quantitative indicators. Observation of the development vector allows us to invest comprehensively in breakthrough directions. This is especially true for assessing the impact of SSH.

attributes.title: Offloading and False Memory - Between Lists

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
As an exploratory analysis, we will also classify recalled words that were not presented (other than the critical lure) as (1) semantically related intrusions, (2) orthographically similar intrusions, (3) unrelated intrusions. We will compare the intrusion rates for Offloading and No-Offloading on the final two trials using paired t-test.

As an exploratory analysis, we will also classify recalled words that were not presented (other than the critical lure) as (1) semantically related intrusions, (2) orthographically similar intrusions, (3) unrelated intrusions. We will compare the intrusion rates for Offloading and No-Offloading in the four trials using paired t-test.

sample.value: The number of observations collected will be N = 80, in order to achieve at least .80 power for a McNemar test based on a predicted odds ratio of 3.5 and 0.34 proportion of discordant pairs (prediction based on previous studies in our lab).

analyses.value:
We will focus our analyses on the final two trials, where participants do not have access to their written lists (offloading vs no offloading).

For our first dependent variable of interest, the recall of the critical lure, we will use a McNemar's test to test whether the proportion of recalling the critical lure for Offloading categories was different from the No-Offloading categories. We will also use mixed effects logistic regression analysis to predict the effect of offloading on this variable (as a fixed effect).

For our second dependent variable of interest, the recall of the presented items, we will use a within-subjects t-test to compare recall of the offloading vs no-offloading items. We will also use a mixed effects logistic regression to predict the effect of offloading on this variable (as a fixed effect).

We have elected to analyze each dependent variable (recall of critical lure and recall of presented items) separately based on previous studies in the literature. However, we will also conduct mixed effects logistic regression with both offloading (Offloading vs. No-Offloading) and item type recalled (Presented Item vs Critical Lure) as factors, and include the interaction term in the model to test for significance.

We will report basic descriptives, e.g., means, 95% CIs.

outliers.value: We will remove participants who do not follow the rules, did not complete the experiment, or switched to a different window during the experiment (as indicated by browser interaction data). These participants will be replaced.

dependent.value:
Key dependent variables:
(1) recall rate for the critical lure, and (2) recall rate for the presented items.

conditions.value:
We have a single independent variable with two levels, Offload and No Offload, manipulated within-subjects.

On the final two trials, for all participants, offloading will be manipulated. 
In one of the trials, participants are not given access to the words they had written down during encoding and are told so ahead of time (no-offloading condition).
In the other trial, participants are not given access to the words they had written down during encoding but are told they will have access (i.e., they expected that they would be able to rely on the written record/external memory store; offloading condition).
The order in which participants are assigned these conditions will be counterbalanced.

On each trial, the words presented will be from a categorized DRM list that reliably produces false recall of a critical lure (e.g. bed, rest, awake; sleep).

hypothesis.value: Does cognitive offloading increase or decrease the formation of false memories?

q1.value: MIRA - Mental Imagery as Reward Amplifier

q2.value: Max Heise, Jessica Werthmann, Fritz Renner

q3.value: Increasing motivation for and actual engagement in adaptive activities is an important treatment target in Cognitive Behavioural Therapy. While it has been shown that simulating engagement in activities through guided mental imagery can increase ratings of anticipated pleasure, reward and motivation for these activities (‘motivational amplifier’ effect; Renner et al, 2019), the precise underlying mechanism remains to be fully understood. As a candidate mechanism the present study investigates 'affective forecasting', i.e. mental imagery’s capacity to generate rich multisensory and emotionally salient experiences of future activities in the present. Preliminary findings of studies from our lab indicate a possible moderating effect of participants' hedonic capacities, as assessed with the Temporal Experience of Pleasure Scale (TEPS; Gard et al., 2006) on the effectiveness of the used guided imagery scripts. To investigate this further, the present study aims to experimentally manipulate processing mode (reward imagery vs. neutral imagery vs. logical reasoning) in a sample with low anticipatory hedonic capacity (i.e. individuals scoring low on the anticipatory subscale of the TEPS).

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1 - Activity ratings. Greater increase in activity ratings (anticipated pleasure, anticipated reward, motivation) from pre- to post experimental manipulation for:
a) neutral imagery condition compared to logical reasoning condition (directional hypothesis)
b) reward imagery condition compared to logical reasoning condition (directional hypothesis)
c) reward imagery condition compared to neutral imagery condition
 ('reward imagery effect', directional hypothesis)

Hypothesis 2 - Number of completed activities. Higher number of completed activities in:
a) neutral imagery condition compared to logical reasoning condition (directional hypothesis)
b) reward imagery condition compared to logical reasoning condition (directional hypothesis)
c) reward imagery condition compared to neutral imagery condition ('reward imagery effect', directional hypothesis)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We have a 3 x 2 mixed design, with condition (3 levels: reward imagery vs. neutral imagery vs. logical reasoning) as between-subject factor and time of measurement (2 levels: pre vs. post experimental manipulation) as within-subject factor.

q9.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three equally sized conditions (reward imagery, neutral imagery, logical reasoning).

Within each condition, the sequence of activity type will be counterbalanced: participants will be randomly assigned to either process three enjoyable activities first followed by three routine activities or vice versa.

The random number list required for both randomizations will be created using the R-package randomizeR (Version: 2.0.0).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from the general public in Freiburg, Germany through the distribution of leaflets and posters across town.

Participants have to fulfil the following inclusion criteria:
· age 18-65 years
· proficiency in German (native speaker or at least level C1)
· no prior participation in mental imagery studies in our lab
· not currently undergoing treatment for any mental illness

Participants will be pre-screened using the TEPS (Gard et al., 2006). Only participants with a score of 4.4 or lower in the TEPS anticipatory subscale will be invited to take part in our study. Cutoff based on data from a previous independent sample.

In return for taking part, participants will be paid 7,50€/hour. Typically, participants will receive credit for a total of three hours (2h lab session, 1h for completing questionnaires in the seven days following the lab session).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 108 participants (n = 36 per condition).

q14.value: The targeted sample size is based on previous studies, pilot data and power considerations.

question.value:
Participants in all conditions will plan in 6 activities to engage in over the week following the lab session.

We plan to manipulate the processing mode of the scheduled activities:

· Reward imagery condition: Participants will be instructed to perform mental imagery exercises explicitly focussing on the pleasant/beneficial outcomes associated with the performance (intrinsic) or completion (extrinsic) of the target activities.
· Neutral imagery condition: Participants will be instructed to perform mental imagery exercises focussing on the procedural details of performing the target activities (i.e. without reference to the affective qualities of the experience).
· Logical reasoning condition: Participants will perform a logical reasoning task for each target activity. In this task, participants are instructed to form a sentence arguing in favor of the target activity based on its short and long term positive consequences and positive emotional outcomes.

We will be using two outcome measures: activity ratings and number of performed activities.

1. Activity ratings will be obtained by asking participants to assess the following statements for each activity (on a continuous scale ranging from 'not at all' to 'extremely'):
· How pleasant/enjoyable do you anticipate engaging in this activity next week will be?
· How rewarding do you expect completing this activity next week will be? 
· How motivated are you to engage in this activity next week?

Activity ratings used in the confirmatory analyses will use each subject's mean score across their six activities.

2. The number of performed activities (possible range: 0 - 6) will be obtained from the 'activity diary' (small booklet returned by participants in a prepaid envelope) completed over the 7 days following the experimental lab session (‘activity week’).

As a secondary outcome we will also be recording heart rate data using an optical wristband heart rate monitor. This measure will be used to conduct exploratory analyses only.

We will include additional questionnaires (e.g. on the use of mental imagery, depressive symptoms) and ratings of the specific activities in our study. However, these measures will not be used in the confirmatory analyses.

· Hypothesis 1: We will conduct separate repeated measures 3x2 ANOVA for each activity rating (anticipated pleasure, anticipated reward, motivation) with condition (3 levels: reward imagery condition, neutral imagery condition, logical reasoning condition) as between-subject factor and time of measurement (2 levels: pre vs. post experimental manipulation) as within-subject factor.
A significant condition x time interaction effect will be followed up by pairwise comparisons to test differences between conditions.

· Hypothesis 2: We will conduct a one-way ANOVA with number of completed activities as dependent variable and condition (3 levels: reward imagery condition, neutral imagery condition, logical reasoning condition) as between-subject factor.
A significant main effect of condition will be followed up by pairwise comparisons to test differences between conditions.

attributes.title: Voices 2: prosodic training program in schizophrenia
attributes.description:
Our project consists in the evaluation of the aplicability of a rehabilitation online program, called Voices. This program is dedicated to prosodic training in patients with
schizophrenia to improve their recognition of basic and complex emotions, resulting, secondarily,
in the simultaneous improvement of social cognition and social competencies. Our hypothesis is
that participants in this prosodic rehabilitation program have better results in prosodic tests than
the ones that participate in a contol group of active placebo treatment. We also want to measure this improvements one month after intervention.

attributes.title: Effectiveness of interventions to help people who sell sexual services to exit prostitution. A systematic review

summary.value:
Due to the intrinsic nature of prostitution, sex workers face to harmful situations for their health and need multiple services. Helping them to exit prostitution could be a relevant strategy to improve their global health and their quality of life. However, the body of evidence about the effectiveness of interventions to help sex workers to exit prostitution is unknown. To our knowledge, some authors have reported the effectiveness of their program to help sex workers to exit prostitution but we have reasons to believe that methodological flaws might affect the internal and external validity of studies. Objective assessment of the effectiveness of interventions to exit sex workers from prostitution is needed to understand what could works in a real-world setting. A synthesis of the studies and an evaluation of the body of evidence on the effectiveness of interventions could inform both research and practice. The objective of this systematic review is to synthesize the evidence about the effectiveness of interventions to help people who sell sexual services to exit prostitution. 
The registered protocol (see attached file) describes the methods used in this systematic review of the literature.

attributes.title: Does the influence of race and gender on perspective-taking and word order during language production replicate?

q1.value: Does the influence of race and gender on perspective-taking and word order during language production replicate?

q2.value: Jessica Brough, Hugh Rabagliati, Holly P. Branigan, Lasana Harris

q3.value:
This study is a replication of ‘The influence of race and gender on perspective-taking and word order during language production’ – pre-registration can be found here: https://osf.io/bfhrn. It explores the possibility of a ‘Like Me’ hierarchy that goes beyond a most animate > least animate hierarchical word ordering, whereby speakers ascribe the position of first-mention to the figure that is most like themselves in identity over someone less similar, when describing an interaction between two figures.

In this study, participants will describe photographs of two actors interacting, who will differ in either gender (‘gender trials’ show man/woman dyads) or race (‘race trials’ show black/white dyads). Participants will be either black or white men and women, and will describe these scenes using so-called symmetrical predicates (Gleitman, Gleitman, Miller, & Ostrin, 1996). These are verbs that imply a symmetry of action between the two figures (e.g. arguing, kissing, touching), but when used in a sentence they require the speaker to make a decision as to which figure should be mentioned first, which may be potentially conditioned on a factor such as animacy.

Participants will form either transitive (e.g. “Jane is arguing with Fred”) or conjoined sentences (e.g. “Jane and Fred are arguing with each other”) to describe the events, which they will type into a text box. We will measure if participants routinely take the perspective of one actor over another, i.e. by mentioning them first in their event descriptions, and we will assess how this varies based on the identity of the actor and the identity of the participant.

Results from the original study supported a ‘Like Me’ explanation for word order choices to an extent, with participants tending to mention the figure of their own gender or race first. However, there were cases where speakers demonstrated a bias in the opposite direction. For example, black and white women were more likely to mention the black woman first and black man second on black gender trials, as predicted, but black women were proportionally more likely to mention the white man first and white woman second on white gender trials, contrary to our predictions, and white women showed no significant bias in either direction.

We must therefore also consider that there are aspects of how particular social groups are perceived which might influence the types of people we consider to be appropriate “agents” and “patients” of events. To understand the decisions a speaker might make about these thematic roles, we will address research from social psychology on biased attitudes and stereotyping. For example, we will consider gendered notions of leadership that favour men over women (Koenig, Eagly, Mitchell, & Ristikari, 2011) and white people over racial minorities as appropriate leaders (Rosette, Leonardelli, & Phillips, 2008), and how individual differences in attitudes towards social groups may influence such biases (Hoyt & Simon, 2016). We will question if biased notions of what makes a prototypical leader or who is perceived as dominant will translate into who speakers perceive as agents in our scenes. For example, research that has taken an intersectional perspective suggests that non-black people perceive dominant behaviours of black women differently to that of white women or black men, but similarly to that of white men (Livingston, Rosette, & Washington, 2012).

As well as differences in the higher order factors that determine how different social groups perceive these same events, another possible reason for the discrepancies in our original findings could be subtle differences in the stimuli (such as the salience of different figures) that could have impacted how attention was allocated when processing the events. A methodological concern of the original study is the quality of the stimuli; on many trials, the two figures differed notably in height (with most men taller than most women) and brightness of clothing (e.g. one figure wearing black while the other was wearing white). In order to discount visual salience as influencing our results, we are running the replication study with a new stimuli set, with figures close in height and wearing coloured clothing of a similar brightness.

q4.value:
First, we hypothesise that there will be effects of race identity and gender identity on perspective-taking. We will measure perspective-taking by recording who participants mention first in their descriptions. We hypothesise that participants will demonstrate a tendency to mention the figure most like themselves first, i.e. the figure who shares either the same racial or gender identity as the participant. For example, we predict that men will mention the man figure before the woman figure on gender trials (those depicting man/woman dyads), and white participants will mention the white figure before the black figure on the race trials (those depicting black/white dyads). As this study is a replication, these predictions are responses to the original experiment, which found significant Like Me bias effects on both gender and race trials. 

Second, we hypothesise that there will be an effect of syntax on mention order. Half of the descriptions participants will produce will involve them constructing either transitive sentences, in which one participant is the agent and one the patient (e.g. Person A is marrying Person B), or conjoined sentences, in which both participants are agents (e.g. Person A and Person B are marrying each other. The addition of “each other” on conjoined sentences is for the purpose of creating the perception of a more symmetrical event than those described with transitive sentences (Gleitman et al., 1996). We predict that participants will be more likely to demonstrate a ‘Like Me’ bias on transitive sentences than on conjoined sentences, as one figure is given greater agenthood than the other and the speaker is required to make judgements of grammatical function (Branigan, Pickering, & Tanaka, 2008).

In the original study, we found a significant main effect of syntax on gender trials (p < .05) with a stronger Like Me Gender bias appearing on transitive trials, but not on race trials.
We will explore the interaction between race and gender on first mention. For instance, we will investigate if participants will be more likely to mention the figure matching their own gender first if that figure is also of the same race as themselves, and are more likely to mention the figure matching their own race if that figure is also the same gender as the participant.

We will also consider how event type might influence mention order, by looking at the valence of the events. Dancing, flirting, kissing, marrying will initially be considered intimate events, arguing, shouting and fighting will be considered negative events, and playing, talking and touching will be coded as casual events. We will measure if patterns of first mention differ between valence conditions (intimate, negative and casual); e.g. we will ask if participants are more likely to demonstrate word order biases on one valence condition than the others.

We will run a factor analysis post-hoc on one participant demographic group (e.g. white men) to determine if our event classifications are appropriate. We will see, based on responses to each event, if the interactions in our three assumed valence groups should in fact be classed with each other (i.e. playing, talking and touching as casual events) due to participants responding similarly to them and differently to the others. 

On gender trials, based on the results of the original study, we predict that participants will mention the man figure first more consistently on intimate events than on casual or negative events, and that when the woman figure is mentioned first this will occur more often on negative events than on casual or intimate events. We will also determine if the effect of trial type replicates; that the Like Me Gender bias was strongest in female participants when they were describing trials depicting black dyads in negative events, and was strongest in male participants when they were describing trials depicting white dyads in intimate events.

On race trials, again referring to the results of the original study, we predict that black participants will show a tendency to mention the black figure first most often on positive events, and that white participants will show a tendency to mention the white participant first most often on negative events.

We will also measure if the Like Me Gender/Like Me Race biases manifest when analysing each valence condition independently.

We consider how the nature of these events may elicit different responses in participants due to attitudes towards particular social groups. Specifically, responses to intimate events between people of the same gender, and between people of different races, might be influenced by the speaker’s attitudes toward homosexuality and interracial relationships respectively. To explore this possibility, we are including a post-study questionnaire to address attitudes towards these two social factors and will use logistic regressions to determine if they had an influence on perceptions of agency on race trials. We predict deviations from predictable patterns of behaviour (i.e. showing a Like Me Race bias) will most likely occur on trials that contradict the speaker’s expectations and accepted world view (e.g. two men shown “marrying”, described by a participant with negative attitudes towards homosexuality).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Prior to beginning the critical trials, participants will view 8 photographs of strangers and their names (2 black men, 2 black women, 2 white men, 2 white women). The photographs are of similar size and the actors wear clothes of a similar brightness, to control for visual salience. We will ask participants to memorise the names and portraits. Next, they will complete a memory task, in which they will have to match the portrait with the correct name. Participants repeat this memory task until they score 100% correct, whereupon they begin the language task. Additionally, to ensure participants remain accurate at naming the photographs, the same memory task will repeat after every 20 trials of the language task, and participants will again have to score 100% correct to continue the language task.

On each critical trial of the language task, participants will view an image of two of the photographed people interacting in a symmetrical event (e.g., touching each other, shouting at each other, hugging each other, etc). They are then shown a sentence fragment (e.g., “is touching”), and they complete the sentence (e.g., writing “Jane is touching Fred”).  The images are formatted as graphics interchange format (GIF) animations, such that the image switches with its Left-Right mirror image twice per second. This is done to ensure that the two photographed people each appear on the left-hand-side and right-hand-side twice, so as to account for English speakers’ tendency to mention the figure who appears on the left first. This is considered to be a reading effect; many adults demonstrate the tendency to look in the order they are used to reading in. This scanning habit is then reflected in the speaker’s subject-verb-object structure (Maass & Russo, 2003). Our prior data suggests that using mirror-reversing images helps participants to avoid a significant orientation bias, either towards the figure who appears on the left-hand-side first or on the left-hand-side last, using this method.

The design of this study is mixed, involving a within-subjects design in which all participants view the same trial type conditions and receive the same syntax manipulation, and a between-subject factor of identity (whether the participant matches the figure in race or gender). We aim to investigate the extent to which mention order, when describing an interaction between two people, is influenced by relative similarity between the depicted figures and the speaker (i.e. if the figure is in the speaker’s in-group they are more similar, if they are in the out-group they are less similar). To do so, we will show people images on ‘gender trials’ in which one figure is always in the participants gender in-group and the other is in their gender out-group, and images on ‘race trials’ in which one figure is always in the participant’s racial in-group and the other is in their racial out-group.

On gender trials, dyads will be a man and a woman of the same race. Half of these trials will depict white man/woman dyads (‘White Trials’) and half will depict black man/woman dyads (‘Black Trials’). On race trials, dyads will be a white person and a black person of the same gender. Half will depict white woman/black woman dyads (‘Woman Trials’) and half will depict white man/black man dyads (‘Man Trials’). Participants will see 40 gender trials and 40 race trials in total.

We will cross the identity condition with a manipulation of sentence structure. In the transitive condition, participants will be instructed to produce active present progressive transitive sentences with an ‘is’ auxiliary (e.g., they will be told to use “is marrying” to describe a situation in which Jane and Fred are marrying each other, so they can either choose the form Jane is marrying Fred or Fred is marrying Jane) and in the conjoined condition, they will produce sentences with a conjoined subject and ‘are’ auxiliary (e.g. Jane and Fred are marrying each other or Fred and Jane are marrying each other). The transitive and intransitive conditions comprise of 40 trials respectively.

q9.value:
We are randomising the order of trials in the memory task and language task. We are counterbalancing which names are assigned to which figures between the experimental lists, so that the names assigned to the figures in list 1A are the same as in List 1B, and are assigned to figures of the other race in lists 2A and 2B (e.g. a white woman is called ‘Kate’ in Lists 1A and 1B and ‘Jane’ in Lists 2A and 2B, while a Black woman is called ‘Jane’ in Lists 1A and 1B and ‘Kate’ in Lists 2A and 2B). 

We are also counterbalancing which figure appears on the left-hand-side first in the GIF stimuli between the experimental lists, so that first figures to appear on the left in list 1A are the same as in List 2A, and first appear on the right-hand-side in lists 1B and 2B.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: This study will be run online via the platform Prolific Academic. Recruitment will be open to Prolific account holders, 18 years old and above, who have self-defined their ethnicity as either Black or white, their sex as either male or female, their gender identity as either male or female, their first language as English and have reported no language-related disorders. Participants will provide descriptions of images by typing them into a text box provided, and will give responses to the questionnaire by typing in answers and clicking a button on the Likert scale.

q13.value: We aim to recruit 240 participants across these demographic groups (i.e. 60 Black women, 60 Black men, 60 white women and 60 white men). Participants of each demographic will be assigned to one of the four experiment lists randomly, so that 15 participants of each group complete each list.

question.value: Independent variables in this study are participant gender (man/woman) and participant race (black/white), trial type (gender trials are comprised of ‘Black Trials’ and ‘White Trials’, race trial types are comprised of ‘Man Trials’ and ‘Woman Trials’) and syntax produced by participants (transitive/conjoined). Our independent variable of valence comprises of intimate events (dancing, flirting, kissing, marrying), negative events (arguing, fighting, shouting) and casual events (playing, talking and touching).

Participants will type their descriptions into a provided text box, and we will code these responses to determine who participants mentioned first in their descriptions. We will code the dependent variable in two different ways; the proportion of trials on which participants mentioned the more socially dominant group first (man first and woman second on gender trials, white person first and black person second on race trials), and the proportion of trials on which speakers took the perspective of the person most like themselves. For this latter dependent variable, we will measure a ‘Like Me’ bias by taking the proportion of gender trials on which participants mentioned the figure of their own gender first (a Like Me Gender bias), and the proportion of race trials on which participants mentioned the figure of their own race first (a Like Me Race bias).

Some of our stimuli depict interactions that may challenge expectations – e.g., intimate events on race trials which all depict same-gender interracial couples. We will take this into consideration when analysing the data, asking if response habits differ for these scenes. To explore this further, we will conduct a post-study questionnaire looking at attitudes towards these social groups. We will measure attitudes toward homosexuality using items obtained from the the European Social Survey (2002 – 2010) and the National Survey of Sexual Attitudes and Lifestyles (Watt & Elliot, 2019) and attitudes toward interracial relationships between black and white people have been adapted from the Cross-Group Relationship Scale (Field, Kimuna & Straus, 2013). Questions will be answered on a 5 Point Likert scale and respondents will also have a “Do not want to say” option to allow them to miss questions they do not wish to answer.

We will measure if scores relating to attitudes towards homosexuality or interracial relations act as predictors of the Like Me Race biases (e.g. if the likelihood of a participant demonstrating a Like Me Race bias decreases the more negatively the participant scores on the homosexuality attitudes scale). We will not do this for the Like Me Gender bias, as gender trials all depict different-gender and same-race pairs.

We will measure if participants who demonstrate notably negative attitudes regarding homosexuality or interracial relationships also demonstrate significant differences in responses to homosexual or interracial intimate scenes compared to heterosexual or same-race intimate scenes. For example, if when describing race trials they habitually mention their own race first on negative and casual race trials, but do not demonstrate the same bias on intimate race trials. 

To determine the extent of an orientation bias, we will measure the proportion of responses on which speakers first mentioned the figure who appeared on the left-hand-side first, or the figure who appeared on the right-hand side first.

Primary Analyses

Analysis 1 looks at the proportion mentioning the dominant group first, and whether this varies by participant gender, participant race and stimulus type. We will take an iterative approach to model building, starting by looking at participant race and participant gender as predictors of mentioning the man first or the white figure first. This mixed effects model will have a 2 * 2 design with the maximal random effects structure for model convergence:

Man First/White First ~ Participant Gender * Participant Race + (1 | Subject) + (1 + Participant Gender + Participant Race | Event).

Following this, we will add trial type as a predictor of first mention:

Man First/White First ~ Participant Gender * Participant Race * [Gender Trial Type or Race Trial Type] + (1 + [Gender Trial Type or Race Trial Type] | Subject) + (1 + Participant Gender + Participant Race | Event).

Lastly, we will add syntax condition as a predictor:

Man First/White First ~ Participant Gender * Participant Race * [Gender Trial Type or Race Trial Type] * Syntax + (1 + [Gender Trial Type or Race Trial Type] + Syntax | Subject) + (1 + Participant Gender + Participant Race | Event).

If any of the models do not converge, we will iteratively remove random effects that account for the least variance.

Data visualizations will be used to identify the direction of significant effects. For the ‘man first’ analysis, we expect that participant gender will be a significant predictor of mentioning the man first, with male participants more likely than chance to mention the man before the woman, while female participants will be significantly less likely to mention the man first. Following results from the original study which showed a significant effect of gender trial type, we predict that the man will be mentioned first more often on white trials than on black trials.

In our original study, the ‘white first’ analysis showed a significant main effect of participant race. We will test if this effect replicates, predicting that white participants will be more likely to mention the white figure before the black figure, while black participants will be significantly less likely to mention the white figure first. Results from the original study also showed a significant main effect of race trial type; participants mentioned the white figure first more often on man trials than on women trials, and so we will test if this effect replicates with these new stimuli.

Analysis 2 focus on the “Like Me” analysis, and looks at the proportion of trials on which participants mention the figure most like them first, and the extent to which this varies by participant gender, participant race, stimulus type and sentence type. As above, we will take an iterative approach to model building, starting by looking at participant gender and participant race as predictors of a Like Me Gender or Like Me Race bias: This is a 2 * 2 design, analysed using a mixed effects model with the maximal random effects structure for model convergence, e.g:

Like Me Gender/Race ~ Participant Gender * Participant Race + (1 | Subject) + (1 + Participant Gender + Participant Race | Event).

Following this, we will add trial type as a fixed effect:

Like Me Gender/Race ~ Participant Gender * Participant Race * [Gender Trial Type or Race Trial Type] + (1 + [Gender Trial Type or Race Trial Type] | Subject) + (1 + Participant Gender + Participant Race | Event).

And lastly, we will add syntax condition as a forth predictor of a Like Me Gender/Race bias:

Like Me Gender/Race ~ Participant Gender * Participant Race * [Gender Trial Type or Race Trial Type] * Syntax + (1 + [Gender Trial Type or Race Trial Type] + Syntax | Subject) + (1 + Participant Gender + Participant Race | Event).

We will follow the same method of model simplification as above. The purpose of this analysis is to determine if all four demographic groups, trial types and syntax conditions are just as likely to demonstrate a Like Me Gender/Race bias or if there are differences between the groups, and if it is more likely to occur on some stimuli or sentence types over others (comparing black/white gender trials, man/woman race trials, and transitive/conjoined sentences).

If our Like Me hypothesis is supported in this replication study, participants will be more likely to firstly mention the character that matches their gender/race, as indicated by a significant intercept in the regression (e.g. a ‘Like Me Gender’ bias would be demonstrated by a woman participant mentioning the woman first on gender trials, and a ‘Like Me Race’ bias would be demonstrated by a black participant mentioning the black figure first on race trials).

For the Like Me Gender analysis in our original study, we found a significant intercept, significant main effects of syntax and participant gender, and a significant interaction between participant gender and gender trial type. For the Like Me Race analysis, we found a significant intercept and interaction between participant race and race trial type, but no main effect of participant race or gender, trial type or syntax. We will test if these results from the original study replicate. Again, data visualizations will be used to identify the direction of significant effects.

To determine if men and women both show a Like Me Gender bias, we will run two separate models for each participant gender. These models will include the fixed effects of participant race, trial type and syntax. Will we do a similar analysis for race trials, running two models for black and white participants individually to determine if they independently show a Like Me Race bias. These models will include the fixed effects of participant gender, trial type and syntax.

We are also interested in how event type influenced mention order biases, and will therefore run models with valence condition as a fixed effect, along participant gender, participant race, trial type and syntax, as predictors of the man first, white first, Like Me Gender and Like Me Race biases. We will see if the results from our original study replicate; that valence was a significant predictor of the man first bias. It did not have a significant main effect on the Like Me Gender bias, but did show a significant interaction with participant gender.

We will then run individual models for each of the valence conditions, to determine if a Like Me Gender/Race bias manifests on all three event types (intimate, negative and casual), as demonstrated by a significant intercept. We will predict the Like Me Gender/Race bias from the fixed effects of participant gender, participant race, trial type and syntax.

Lastly, we will run regressions to analyse the questionnaire data, by taking each participants’ average score for their attitude towards homosexuality and interracial relationships independently and using these as predictors of demonstrating a Like Me Race bias overall and on each event type, with a particular interest in intimate events. Individual items will be excluded from the analysis if they demonstrate a very low item-total correlation, as determined by falling below 0.5 Cronbach's α. We will also take an iterative approach to model building here, beginning by looking at attitudes towards homosexuality and interracial relationships as predictors of a Like Me Race bias: 

Like Me Race ~ Scale(Homosexuality_Attitude) * Scale(Interracial_Attitude) + (1 | Subject) + (1 + Scale(Homosexuality_Attitude) + Scale(Interracial_Attitude) | Event).

Next, we will add participant gender and participant race as predictors in the model:

Like Me Race ~ Scale(Homosexuality_Attitude) * Scale(Interracial_Attitude) * Participant Gender * Participant Race + (1 | Subject) + (1 + Participant Gender + Participant Race + Scale(Homosexuality_Attitude) + Scale(Interracial_Attitude) | Event).

Then we will add trial type as a predictor of demonstrating a Like Me Race bias:

Like Me Race ~ Scale(Homosexuality_Attitude) * Scale(Interracial_Attitude) * Participant Gender * Participant Race * Race Trial Type + (1 + Race Trial Type | Subject) + (1 + Participant Gender + Participant Race + Scale(Homosexuality_Attitude) + Scale(Interracial_Attitude) | Event).

And, finally, we will add syntax as a fixed effect in the model:

Like Me Race ~ Scale(Homosexuality_Attitude) * Scale(Interracial_Attitude) * Participant Gender * Participant Race * Race Trial Type * Syntax + (1 + Race Trial Type + Syntax | Subject) + (1 + Participant Gender + Participant Race + Scale(Homosexuality_Attitude) + Scale(Interracial_Attitude) | Event).

We will iteratively remove random effects that account for the least variance on models that do not converge.


	
Secondary Analyses

We will also repeat the secondary control analyses conducted in our first study. First, we will investigate the effects of participant age as a predictor of mention order (though we do not predict a significant effect of age, as in the original experiment), and a change in preferred mention order across the experiment timeline (i.e. does the strength of a mention order bias change between the start and the end of the experiment). We will test if our findings from the original study replicate; firstly that the bias towards mentioning men first decreases over the course of the experiment and the Like Me Gender bias increases, particularly for female participants. Secondly, that the Like Me Race bias decreases over the course of the experiment.

A further control analysis examines participants’ accuracy at remembering the names of the photographed figures. If participant groups systematically differ in their ability to remember the names of different figures (e.g., white men participants making fewer mistakes on white men’s names), we would have to consider this as an explanation for potential differences in mention order. Therefore we will investigate the data collected during the first round of the memory task, to determine if participants showed a bias for remembering stimuli of particular demographics. Our measure of accuracy will be correct guesses on each trial. To analyse, we will run a model predicting accuracy by participant gender and race, and stimuli gender and race. Following the results from the original experiment, we do not expect to find either of these fixed effects to significantly predict accuracy.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the regressions suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value:
Trials will be excluded where the participant does not use the correct syntax in their descriptions (e.g. they are given “is hugging” for a transitive description prompt and respond with an intransitive “Mike and Beth are hugging each other”) or the correct names for the figures (e.g. they type “Fred and Beth” instead of “Mike and Beth”). Trials where participants have made a clear typing error that does not signify a figure identification or syntax use error will not be excluded (e.g. the participant has typed “Miike”, “Moke” or “iss hugging”). We will calculate the overall mean trial response time and standard deviation for each participant and will exclude trials with a response time greater than 3 standard deviations from this mean.

Participants who do not provide the correct syntax on at least 50% of transitive trials and 50% of intransitive trials will be excluded. Participants who do not provide valid responses on at least 50% of trials and exceed the maximum experiment completion time of 60 minutes will be excluded. Participants who demonstrate an orientation bias for mentioning either the figure who appears on the left first on over 90% of trials, or the figure who appears on the right first on over 90% of trials, will be excluded.

We will run a reliability analysis on questionnaire items, independently for attitudes towards homosexuality and interracial relationships, which will be excluded if they demonstrate a very low item-total correlation, as determined by falling below 0.5 Cronbach's α.

q23.value: Trials with missing responses will be excluded. Any analyses that utilise the questionnaire measures regarding attitudes towards homosexuality or interracial relationships will exclude participants who did not complete all the related the questions (responses of ‘Do not want to say’ will also be classed as invalid). Additionally, questionnaire analyses will exclude participants who routinely select the same response on over 90% of trials.

q24.value: It is possible that typicality might influence the likelihood of speakers mentioning their own in-group first (e.g. speakers are more likely to do so on events that do not contradict their expectations of a “typical scene”). Following a post-hoc norming study, we will use ratings of typicality to investigate how this factor may have influenced responses to particular trials.

registration_responses.q1: Does the influence of race and gender on perspective-taking and word order during language production replicate?
registration_responses.q2: Jessica Brough, Hugh Rabagliati, Holly P. Branigan, Lasana Harris
registration_responses.q3:
This study is a replication of ‘The influence of race and gender on perspective-taking and word order during language production’ – pre-registration can be found here: https://osf.io/bfhrn. It explores the possibility of a ‘Like Me’ hierarchy that goes beyond a most animate > least animate hierarchical word ordering, whereby speakers ascribe the position of first-mention to the figure that is most like themselves in identity over someone less similar, when describing an interaction between two figures.

In this study, participants will describe photographs of two actors interacting, who will differ in either gender (‘gender trials’ show man/woman dyads) or race (‘race trials’ show black/white dyads). Participants will be either black or white men and women, and will describe these scenes using so-called symmetrical predicates (Gleitman, Gleitman, Miller, & Ostrin, 1996). These are verbs that imply a symmetry of action between the two figures (e.g. arguing, kissing, touching), but when used in a sentence they require the speaker to make a decision as to which figure should be mentioned first, which may be potentially conditioned on a factor such as animacy.

Participants will form either transitive (e.g. “Jane is arguing with Fred”) or conjoined sentences (e.g. “Jane and Fred are arguing with each other”) to describe the events, which they will type into a text box. We will measure if participants routinely take the perspective of one actor over another, i.e. by mentioning them first in their event descriptions, and we will assess how this varies based on the identity of the actor and the identity of the participant.

Results from the original study supported a ‘Like Me’ explanation for word order choices to an extent, with participants tending to mention the figure of their own gender or race first. However, there were cases where speakers demonstrated a bias in the opposite direction. For example, black and white women were more likely to mention the black woman first and black man second on black gender trials, as predicted, but black women were proportionally more likely to mention the white man first and white woman second on white gender trials, contrary to our predictions, and white women showed no significant bias in either direction.

We must therefore also consider that there are aspects of how particular social groups are perceived which might influence the types of people we consider to be appropriate “agents” and “patients” of events. To understand the decisions a speaker might make about these thematic roles, we will address research from social psychology on biased attitudes and stereotyping. For example, we will consider gendered notions of leadership that favour men over women (Koenig, Eagly, Mitchell, & Ristikari, 2011) and white people over racial minorities as appropriate leaders (Rosette, Leonardelli, & Phillips, 2008), and how individual differences in attitudes towards social groups may influence such biases (Hoyt & Simon, 2016). We will question if biased notions of what makes a prototypical leader or who is perceived as dominant will translate into who speakers perceive as agents in our scenes. For example, research that has taken an intersectional perspective suggests that non-black people perceive dominant behaviours of black women differently to that of white women or black men, but similarly to that of white men (Livingston, Rosette, & Washington, 2012).

As well as differences in the higher order factors that determine how different social groups perceive these same events, another possible reason for the discrepancies in our original findings could be subtle differences in the stimuli (such as the salience of different figures) that could have impacted how attention was allocated when processing the events. A methodological concern of the original study is the quality of the stimuli; on many trials, the two figures differed notably in height (with most men taller than most women) and brightness of clothing (e.g. one figure wearing black while the other was wearing white). In order to discount visual salience as influencing our results, we are running the replication study with a new stimuli set, with figures close in height and wearing coloured clothing of a similar brightness.
registration_responses.q4:
First, we hypothesise that there will be effects of race identity and gender identity on perspective-taking. We will measure perspective-taking by recording who participants mention first in their descriptions. We hypothesise that participants will demonstrate a tendency to mention the figure most like themselves first, i.e. the figure who shares either the same racial or gender identity as the participant. For example, we predict that men will mention the man figure before the woman figure on gender trials (those depicting man/woman dyads), and white participants will mention the white figure before the black figure on the race trials (those depicting black/white dyads). As this study is a replication, these predictions are responses to the original experiment, which found significant Like Me bias effects on both gender and race trials. 

Second, we hypothesise that there will be an effect of syntax on mention order. Half of the descriptions participants will produce will involve them constructing either transitive sentences, in which one participant is the agent and one the patient (e.g. Person A is marrying Person B), or conjoined sentences, in which both participants are agents (e.g. Person A and Person B are marrying each other. The addition of “each other” on conjoined sentences is for the purpose of creating the perception of a more symmetrical event than those described with transitive sentences (Gleitman et al., 1996). We predict that participants will be more likely to demonstrate a ‘Like Me’ bias on transitive sentences than on conjoined sentences, as one figure is given greater agenthood than the other and the speaker is required to make judgements of grammatical function (Branigan, Pickering, & Tanaka, 2008).

In the original study, we found a significant main effect of syntax on gender trials (p < .05) with a stronger Like Me Gender bias appearing on transitive trials, but not on race trials.
We will explore the interaction between race and gender on first mention. For instance, we will investigate if participants will be more likely to mention the figure matching their own gender first if that figure is also of the same race as themselves, and are more likely to mention the figure matching their own race if that figure is also the same gender as the participant.

We will also consider how event type might influence mention order, by looking at the valence of the events. Dancing, flirting, kissing, marrying will initially be considered intimate events, arguing, shouting and fighting will be considered negative events, and playing, talking and touching will be coded as casual events. We will measure if patterns of first mention differ between valence conditions (intimate, negative and casual); e.g. we will ask if participants are more likely to demonstrate word order biases on one valence condition than the others.

We will run a factor analysis post-hoc on one participant demographic group (e.g. white men) to determine if our event classifications are appropriate. We will see, based on responses to each event, if the interactions in our three assumed valence groups should in fact be classed with each other (i.e. playing, talking and touching as casual events) due to participants responding similarly to them and differently to the others. 

On gender trials, based on the results of the original study, we predict that participants will mention the man figure first more consistently on intimate events than on casual or negative events, and that when the woman figure is mentioned first this will occur more often on negative events than on casual or intimate events. We will also determine if the effect of trial type replicates; that the Like Me Gender bias was strongest in female participants when they were describing trials depicting black dyads in negative events, and was strongest in male participants when they were describing trials depicting white dyads in intimate events.

On race trials, again referring to the results of the original study, we predict that black participants will show a tendency to mention the black figure first most often on positive events, and that white participants will show a tendency to mention the white participant first most often on negative events.

We will also measure if the Like Me Gender/Like Me Race biases manifest when analysing each valence condition independently.

We consider how the nature of these events may elicit different responses in participants due to attitudes towards particular social groups. Specifically, responses to intimate events between people of the same gender, and between people of different races, might be influenced by the speaker’s attitudes toward homosexuality and interracial relationships respectively. To explore this possibility, we are including a post-study questionnaire to address attitudes towards these two social factors and will use logistic regressions to determine if they had an influence on perceptions of agency on race trials. We predict deviations from predictable patterns of behaviour (i.e. showing a Like Me Race bias) will most likely occur on trials that contradict the speaker’s expectations and accepted world view (e.g. two men shown “marrying”, described by a participant with negative attitudes towards homosexuality).
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9:
We are randomising the order of trials in the memory task and language task. We are counterbalancing which names are assigned to which figures between the experimental lists, so that the names assigned to the figures in list 1A are the same as in List 1B, and are assigned to figures of the other race in lists 2A and 2B (e.g. a white woman is called ‘Kate’ in Lists 1A and 1B and ‘Jane’ in Lists 2A and 2B, while a Black woman is called ‘Jane’ in Lists 1A and 1B and ‘Kate’ in Lists 2A and 2B). 

We are also counterbalancing which figure appears on the left-hand-side first in the GIF stimuli between the experimental lists, so that first figures to appear on the left in list 1A are the same as in List 2A, and first appear on the right-hand-side in lists 1B and 2B.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We aim to recruit 240 participants across these demographic groups (i.e. 60 Black women, 60 Black men, 60 white women and 60 white men). Participants of each demographic will be assigned to one of the four experiment lists randomly, so that 15 participants of each group complete each list.
registration_responses.q21: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the regressions suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.
registration_responses.q22:
Trials will be excluded where the participant does not use the correct syntax in their descriptions (e.g. they are given “is hugging” for a transitive description prompt and respond with an intransitive “Mike and Beth are hugging each other”) or the correct names for the figures (e.g. they type “Fred and Beth” instead of “Mike and Beth”). Trials where participants have made a clear typing error that does not signify a figure identification or syntax use error will not be excluded (e.g. the participant has typed “Miike”, “Moke” or “iss hugging”). We will calculate the overall mean trial response time and standard deviation for each participant and will exclude trials with a response time greater than 3 standard deviations from this mean.

Participants who do not provide the correct syntax on at least 50% of transitive trials and 50% of intransitive trials will be excluded. Participants who do not provide valid responses on at least 50% of trials and exceed the maximum experiment completion time of 60 minutes will be excluded. Participants who demonstrate an orientation bias for mentioning either the figure who appears on the left first on over 90% of trials, or the figure who appears on the right first on over 90% of trials, will be excluded.

We will run a reliability analysis on questionnaire items, independently for attitudes towards homosexuality and interracial relationships, which will be excluded if they demonstrate a very low item-total correlation, as determined by falling below 0.5 Cronbach's α.
registration_responses.q23: Trials with missing responses will be excluded. Any analyses that utilise the questionnaire measures regarding attitudes towards homosexuality or interracial relationships will exclude participants who did not complete all the related the questions (responses of ‘Do not want to say’ will also be classed as invalid). Additionally, questionnaire analyses will exclude participants who routinely select the same response on over 90% of trials.
registration_responses.q24: It is possible that typicality might influence the likelihood of speakers mentioning their own in-group first (e.g. speakers are more likely to do so on events that do not contradict their expectations of a “typical scene”). Following a post-hoc norming study, we will use ratings of typicality to investigate how this factor may have influenced responses to particular trials.

This is a replication of a previously pre-registered study, which can be found here:
https://osf.io/bfhrn
